I been playing one of your rivals moon rider for a while and enjoyed it but there was some problems so I got this game. Those problems are gone but some new ones have arrived. Here's the pros and cons and improvements:

Pros: hit detection is superior to it's rivals thanks to larger blocks.
wide area of play allowing for a smoother experience and easier to hit blocks.

Cons/improvements: not many songs for price but that will improve over time naturally.
a lot of the songs seem to be missing large chunks of the song so that immediately throws you off.
The ducking walls are a good same nightmare for is talk people despite calibration.
There's no way to adjust the vibration intensity as more me it's too high when hitting blocks and especially when touching sabers.
It doesn't feel smooth to play overall because of the track design since there in a situation where your arms work separately rather than in unison.
It doesn't feel smooth because the method of hitting the blocks are mixed together such as switching from an up and down to a side to side without a noticeable break or sound change to justify it.
Some songs lag so sound to vibration and visuals are out of sync such as overkill and as a musician it just makes you want to drop the controllers.

Overall I want to like this game but at this stage currently it feels like I'm forcing myself to like it hope to see some improvements in the future.

SO ADDICTING! spending hours trying to complete the time expert+ level I have been trying for so dang long has been my latest quarantine hobby. such a satisfying game to play, and finishing a hard level is so rewarding. it’s a great workout too! if you are looking for a fun way to exercise or just have loads of fun smashing blocks this is the game for you.

I don’t even know where to start! A 1000% great choice to buy for everything within the game. The timing and the different color choices, along with the diversity of the music.

However, the custom songs available on the Rift and other VR formats would be an excellent addition for the Quest, as it helps make the game more interesting towards people who want to play their favorite songs.

Obviously, it’s a brilliant game and there is a clear amount of effort put into it. Would buy for twice the price!
Best quest game hands down. Also super easy to mod

One of the thing I hate most about the ongoing global pandemic is that I could not train as much or as effectively as I would like... and then I bought a Quest and played Beat Saber. 

Boy, does this game make me sweat! It’s both deceptively easy to pick up and play and incredibly deep and challenging. It doesn’t hold back on making you sweat, but it does so while providing a really fun and gorgeous game for you to enjoy. It’s basically a Trojan horse for getting a good cardio exercise. 

I highly recommend the game to anyone with a VR headset, period. Hopefully you can play it on the Quest in its full, untethered glory. 

Enjoy a good cardio while having fun? I’m all in!
review_title: Stuck at home and want to train? BS FTW

Have you ever been to a friends house, or had friends over, and things got a little boring?

It’s so simple to understand. And if you practice it enough, you’ll be able to really impress your friends. They will be happy about how they completed a level on normal difficulty, then you go and get a full combo on expert+. 

Another way this game is 100% worth it to buy is because with some mods, you can download custom songs. This means that there’s is always something new! 

If I could, I’d give this game a 6 star review, it’s that good!

Beat saber is easily my favourite game to play alone, with my family, and when I have friends over. It’s easy to grasp and very rewarding after you finally finish a level you’ve been stuck on for hours.

I'll compare it to Dance Central VR (DCVR) [ I absolutely luv too] which is also an excellent rhythm game, but much less popular. This will emphasise what Beat Sabre has nailed.

THE GOOD:

(1) The 5 difficulty levels for each song means that that it's learning curve is gradual for the first set of difficulty levels (easy, normal, hard), then the last two (Expert, Expert+) are more suited to those who are addicted or just have Jedi skills. 
DCVR's downfall was having only 2 difficulty levels. Easy to get into, but hard to master (so most gave up completely).

(2) Absolutely anyone can play due to it's simplicity. I believe this is why it's popular and because swinging and slicing boxes feels natural and very satisfying.
DCVR on the other hand appears to be very niche (interest). Also ppl aren't natural dancers which would be off putting. I ranked high on the DC leaderboards, but I definitely never had any FINESSE when dancing a routine.

(3) This is the only game where I've found that 'muscle memory' has had a huge impact to the game. I'm able to slices boxes with my hands moving simultaneouly in different directions without consciously thinking about it. It makes me feel like Superman, and therefore is very satisfying.
DCVR is polar opposite. I had to painstakingly learn routines, with large amount of time in the studio, rather than actually dancing.

THE BAD:

(1) The game is sold at top price which I believe is way over priced. This is a very simple game conceptually and the development effort requied to build it would have been minimal. I enjoy the game, but at the same time feel rorted solely because it has proven popular / in demand. I have deducted one star rating because of this.
DCVR's development would have been many times greater taking into account;
- 7 room scale locations in a nightclub
- modelling of DC buddies and NPC crowd
- motion capture of dance routines
- system that needs to evaluate players movements in comparison to the dance routine

(2) Songs are mostly EDM (without lyrics) from unknown artists. The popular music is performed by only several artists (each artist has many songs to choose from) which is all DLC at additional cost.
review_title: Very good, but not value for your money!

I tried the Demo last December and was concreted, partly because of the song 'Escape' and how easy it was to pick up and play.

This is significant to me as I'm not the best at rhythm games, particularly DDR as mentioned or even Rock Band since in those games, your only options were either too easy (and boring) or downright impossible (and not fun) and those game required you to get good in order to have fun or you fail, game over. This game certainly has that level of complexity (Expert+ is almost GH3 levels of insane) but that's why I'm happy that there are level modifiers so that this game's audience is not isolated and beginners like me can enjoy the songs on 'Easy' or 'Normal' (No shame!) while also getting a workout.

The Campaign would be my only nitpick though as the later levels have ridiculous winning conditions like having to deliberately miss notes so as not to cross a combo threshold, but that risks failing the level anyway. Thankfully its entirely optional as everything in the game from songs to visuals to colours (bar DLC) is available to you and you don't have to unlock anything to just jump in and have fun cutting cubes to rather awesome music.

In terms of 'Rhythm' and 'Music' games on the Oculus Quest, I recommend this over the others, though the Demo gave me leeway to try before buying and a slight bias, I might look elsewhere though for specifically 'Dancing' and 'Fitness' as harder levels require less arm movement and there's only one song that focusses on fitness.

Honestly, there should be more Demos on the Oculus Store!

First, I'm going to talk about the game and then I'll talk about the quest port. 

Beat Saber is a very addictive game that's easy for everyone to pick up but hard to master. It combines simple mechanics with rhythm based gaming for a unique experience. The game itself is amazing and is definitely worth a try and I highly reccomend that you do so.

The quest port however isn't as great. If this is your first time playing then this section won't be as meaningful. But if you're coming from PCVR then you're going to want to hear this.

The game will cheat you out of a lot of hits. No, not because it's rigged or anything but because, for some unknown reason, some hits just won't register. It's not a tracking issue nor is it a sound sync issue. It's almost like after "x" amount of blocks, the next one will be off beat by just enough to make you miss if you're on rhythm. I've played Beat Saber both through this quest version and the link version and it's only a problem with the standalone app. And with about 150 hours sunk into the pc version, I think it's more than just "I'm playing bad." I feel like this is a legitimate concern as I couldn't play for more than an hour before wanting to return it. (I got denied even though I never went over 2 hours, I kept track, and owned it for less than 3 hours.)

So, tldr:

This game is worth it and you should totally give it a shot. But if you're coming from PCVR or even PSVR you might want to reconsider.

one_reviews_text:
This game is by far my favorite game. If I feel like I haven't had enough exercise today, I play. If I'm feeling down and wanna cut stuff while jamming to sick beats, I play. If I'm just bored, I play.

But where the heck is online multiplayer? I wanna play competitively against my friends, in the moment. Not switching out users on a headset, or checking the score later, but being able to host a match, and when all players are ready, start the song. I first thought that there was only one option for beat saber songs and the difficulty was the only way to change things up. But I was very wrong. Not only are there different ways to play, such as one saber and 360 degrees, but there is also a whole bunch of modifiers that you can apply to make it easier or harder, such as no arrows or ghost notes. (Which I found very challenging) All of that to say that it is going to take a crud ton of playing to get bored of this game and it is definitely worth the $30, even though this might seem pricey to some people. Great game 👍

Pros: 
Excellent aerobic workout - playing this game on hard or higher for as little as half an hour will defiantly get your heart rate up. 

Sense of accomplishment - as you progress through the difficulties and get experience, what seemed like an impossibility will seem like second nature after a short while. 

Endlessly replayable - the game is just satisfying to play, whether just trying to beat your high score, trying to ace a level or just to relax after work


Cons:
Limited songs - the majority of official songs available are either originals or a mere handful of songs from artists you may or may not like. If playing songs you know it's a must (Like for my wife) check out the song list before you purchase unless your happy downloading fan made levels. 

Unresponsive controls - might be just my unit, but several times the lag  between moving the controller and the game responding has been at least half a second causing me to miss easy notes, which for a rythem game is kinda bad 


Overall: 
Although the single most expensive game I've purchased to date, it's also the game I've played the most, whether in my lunch break at work, or at home.

The time commitment per session is miniscule (Got 10 minutes? you got time to play) so it's easy to get into. 

You can play it competitively at parties to see who can get the best score, or by yourself just to master the the thrill. 

Defiantly recommend

I have been playing Beat Saber since I received my Oculus Quest over a year ago, and in the process, I’ve actually lost 20 lbs! In reality, you can play the game with minimal physical activity, but it is so much more fun to chop those cubes with big sweeping movements. When I first started playing, I looked at the EXPERT level of difficulty and thought that it would be impossible to survive the onslaught! But now that’s all I play. My coordination has improved greatly through many hours of play.  Many times, I have become so immersed in the game, that I move out of fear of cutting myself with the light saber.

I do think however, that maybe the Add-ons could be updated. I understand getting song rights may be a hassle and simply not possible. PS keep reading this if you are the developer because I have a recommendation.

I recently bought the oculus quest and was looking for games to buy. I saw  Beat Saber and thought it looked fun enough until I could find another game. But when I played it, I felt something in this game that I haven’t felt in any other game. It’s really satisfying to chop the blocks in half to the beat of the song in the background. This has quickly become one of my favorite games for virtual reality.

Just dont record what you look like outside of the game, because it probably looks pretty silly!

These recent updates have removed the thrills of the game, particularly the graphics of the walls and such. The walls with its previous graphics gave the players a sense of speed and rhythm, but now that they are removed, the maps lack a sense of speed. Its kind of like we are just standing there floating because it doesn’t seem like the walls are moving at all.

Other than that, the gameplay is pretty decent and at the top of my list of games to play.
one of those game that is a timeless master piece

It's a good fun to play game that anyone can play strait out of the gate. Can get pretty difficult but there is a decent progression of difficulty lvls so you can learn at your pace. good game for getting the blood pumping. Song choice is very limited tho. It's all techno dance stuff. Kinda boring. Keep your hands in front of you cause if they go to your side or somehow to far toward the back of your head the quest loses them and you'll probably miss. I don't know about anybody else but I have horrible tracking issues with the quest. It's constantly losing track of the right controller the most. I've tried everything I could find to fix it. Besides the song choice and tracking is the huge leap from expert to expert+ in difficulty. It's horrible. There needs to be another difficulty level between them to smooth out the progression. But other than my little gripes here it's a decent and fun game anyone can play. But not worth $30 in my opinion. If you can, wait till it comes down to half that price.
review_title: This game will tire you out.

one_reviews_text:
As a lover of the good old Dancing Stage games, Best Saber is the modern day equivalent that reminds of just how engaging rhythm games are. The levels are inspiring challenging, so make good use of the practice mode for those tougher levels. The main  improvement I would like to see would be more available pop tracks, whether that's add on or included, though the ones created for the game are very catchy and great tunes. Also, better explanation of the customisable options would be good, as I'm changing the custom colours, I wasn't sure what the colours that I was changing were. That and possibly a longer campaign, but that's assuming that it will end when I reach the last of the three points on the map I have left that are visible. 

Overall, a fantastic game and one I've already invested many hours in.

This is an astonishing game due to the graphics motion and accessibility but it only lost one star for the fact that it only has a limited amount of song unless you wire it to a computer which just, lets be honest here, takes away the special things from the oculus quest and how it’s wireless.

I think if you update it we should get more songs or even better be able to search any song that is on beat saber.

But it is still one of my top five games. Well done 👍

You can't play your own music and yous are not offering much in the game  , the music you have sucks  let the people choose there own music instead of yous being money hungry charging people to have more song, your game isn't worth the money

one_reviews_text:
The core mechanic is so incredibly satisfying, the vibration through the controllers when slicing blocks, crossing your sabres or dragging them through walls is fantastic.
The game has a huge amount of gameplay with a significant replay ability factor to go along with it, The core campaign is great for introduction to new mechanics and challenges which then make way for solo play where you chose the song.

Great game for daily activity during Covid

This game is a must-buy. It has many great songs and very good graphics. I love how you can change the colors of everything￼, and also how fun it is to play. I will play this for at least an hour at a time. It’s good exercise for quarantine.

This game, it’s an exercise under the identity of a game, it’s a real workout that gets you moving quite a lot. I especially love doing boulevard of broken dreams expert+ on the 170% speed in the practice mode, though I do dislike the sabers’ lengths, being one arms length each, it’s still fun to play, aside from a lot of my swings slicing through the blocks and not registering XD though, that’s all I dislike about the game. I’d love to see custom songs reach the quest though. Thanks for reading ^_^

This game is undoubtedly a must have for any vr headset. Its unfortunate that you can’t add custom songs but I understand why the devs had to do it. I do have one recommendation though. A modifier that gives you a sort of “last chance” mode if you run out of energy where the song slows down for a bit and you have a small amount of time to gain your energy back before you lose the level. Another idea I have is a sort of song milestone type of thing where you get some sort badge or something for completing a song on expert plus with insta-fail for example. This is though an amazing game and highly recommended for anyone new to vr or vr veterans.
Easy way to spend time listening to addictive music and burning calories at the same time. Love this game!

This game might sound boring if you haven’t played it before. I mean all you do is swing your arms in different directions. But after you play it, it’s a whole different story. This game is amazing! The music is great, the tracking is excellent, the game is very well made, and new content is constantly being added. When your in the game and music is blasting and your hitting every block and your heart is pumping, it’s just an amazing feeling. And if your having any doubts, just try the demo. That’s how I got into the game. And also, the game has a campaign! You don’t just select songs and play. The campaign has a lot of levels that increase in difficulty and is really fun to play. This game is really fun and I recommend it 100 percent. If I could, I would rate it a hundred stars. To the developers, great work and keep adding new content!

I do have some specific challenges in vr due to some medical conditions, however, beat saber is perfect for me. I used to look a videos of people playing and wonder, can I do that, or....would I early want to? I just didn’t get the appeal, but I got my quest and it came with a demo level of beat saber. I finished it after some difficulty and immediately bought the full version, bought new cables to try to see if I could somehow get more maps, and in the interim, since that failed for now, I am purchasing a majority of the dlc. If you think you can’t do it or it won’t be fun, I promise you will not only enjoy it, it may become a new addition to your daily exercise routine!

Have been playing this on the PS4 with PSVR in expert+ and using virtual desktop in steam VR, with a good network setup u can play expert+. BUT tracking is BEST with Native install of beat saber on the quest the quest keeps up with the tracking of expert+ songs even with custom songs. If you are a pro Beat Saber player that plays expert+ songs makes sure u get it NATIVE installed on the quest for perfect tracking.  If you area a streamer use the oculus mixed reality, its painful to setup but it will stream native quest games in mixed reality well.

The lack of cloud save is especially egregious given the Oculus quest's insanely easy way to factory reset your device. I've owned the quest for a month now and accidentally factory reset twice. The first time I climbed all the way back up the campaign ladder to where I was, but I couldn't bring myself to play those early levels again after the second time. Would be a perfect game if it had cloud save
review_title: Great game, but no cloud save

one_reviews_text: Compared to BeatSaber on other platforms, this one feels like the sabres aren’t aiming directly in the direction you’re pointing. You can mess with this in game but it’s a tad bit confusing compared to other platforms but apart from this minor detail it’s a well fleshed out version, which runs great on the Quest!
For a 30 dollar game, it is amazing. And also, there are so much more than the regular songs. You can buy add-ons, AND use side quest to play custom songs! It is truly amazing.

Only thing I would say is that it is the only game that dose not work for me when I try to use Bluetooth speakers so friends can hear the game as they watch. Other than that great game definitely recommend.

The hits are supposed to be loud, in your face, and punky. Other than that it's a good game.

The one thing holding this back is the lack of content. The game is fundamentally great! The environments, custom modifiers, the responsiveness, everything is so so good! I just wish if had more content. The couple dozen no-name songs make it feel more like a $30 demo than a full game and having to pay for additional songs (only another couple dozen, mostly still no-name tunes) sucks.

This game is only truly worth buying if you were to mod it to allow custom beatmaps.
